statement.text: Valve-sparing aortic root replacement preserves the native aortic valve while replacing the dilated root, avoiding lifelong anticoagulation and offering excellent long-term outcomes in experienced centers for patients with suitable valve anatomy.
statement.formal: Valve-Sparing: Native_Valve_Preserved + Root_Replaced â†’ No_Anticoagulation + Excellent_Durability

explanation.intuition: Instead of throwing away a functioning valve along with the diseased aorta, valve-sparing surgery keeps your own valve and rebuilds a new root around it. This avoids blood thinners and has a lower risk of valve-related complications.
explanation.key_insight: Valve-sparing is preferred in younger patients with Marfan who have normal or near-normal valve leaflets. The David reimplantation technique has better long-term freedom from aortic regurgitation than Yacoub remodeling in connective tissue disorders.
explanation.technical_details: David technique: aortic valve suspended inside a Dacron graft (reimplantation), provides stable annular support. Yacoub technique: sinuses recreated with graft scalloped to fit between commissures (remodeling), less annular support. Selection: David preferred in Marfan (annular stability), Yacoub for normal annulus. Requirements: experienced surgeon, normal or reparable leaflets, not severely calcified. Outcomes: 85-90% freedom from reoperation at 10-15 years.

techniques.David_reimplantation: Valve suspended inside cylindrical graft - provides annular stabilization
techniques.Yacoub_remodeling: Graft scalloped to recreate sinuses - preserves root geometry

clinical_features.selection: David preferred in connective tissue disorders for annular support
